title: How to take a great picture - Carolina Molinari

options.text: To control the shutter speed

options.label: B
options.text: To adjust the ISO sensitivity

options.label: C
options.text: To regulate the amount of light that enters the camera

options.label: D
options.text: To focus the image

options.label: A

options.label: B

options.label: C
options.text: It remains the same

options.label: D
options.text: It becomes distorted

options.label: A

options.label: B

options.label: C
options.text: To regulate the exposure time

options.label: D
options.text: To focus the image

options.label: A

options.label: B
options.text: It remains the same

options.label: C
options.text: It becomes noisier

options.label: D
options.text: It becomes distorted

options.label: B

options.label: C
options.text: The camera's built-in flash

options.label: D

title: Mysteries of vernacular: Sarcophagus - Jessica Oreck and Rachael Teel

multiple-choice.question: What does the term "sarcophagus" originally refer to in the early Roman Empire?

options.text: A type of limestone used in construction

options.label: B
options.text: A type of coffin made from limestone

options.label: C
options.text: A stone monument built to honor the deceased

options.label: D
options.text: A burial ground for the Roman Empire

options.label: A
options.text: It would remain intact and not decay

options.label: B
options.text: It would decay at a normal rate

options.label: C
options.text: It would dissolve and disappear

options.label: D
options.text: It would turn into stone

options.label: A
options.text: From the Greek words "sark" meaning stone and "phagein" meaning to build

options.label: B
options.text: From the Greek words "sark" meaning flesh and "phagein" meaning to eat

options.label: C
options.text: From the Greek words "sark" meaning to construct and "phagein" meaning to decay

options.label: D

options.label: B

options.label: C
options.text: To protect the deceased from decay and damage

options.label: D

title: The terrors of sleep paralysis - Ami Angelowicz

multiple-choice.question: What is the medical condition where a person wakes up feeling like they are being suffocated by an evil entity, but they are actually paralyzed and unable to move?

options.label: A
options.text: Sleepwalking

options.label: B
options.text: Insomnia

options.label: C
options.text: Sleep paralysis

options.label: D
options.text: Narcolepsy

multiple-choice.question: According to Dr. Silas Weir Mitchell, what happens during an episode of sleep paralysis?

options.label: A
options.text: The person is wide awake and able to move freely.

options.label: B
options.text: The person is asleep and unable to move.

options.label: C
options.text: The person is engaged in a struggle for movement, fraught with acute mental distress.

options.label: D
options.text: The person is experiencing a normal REM cycle.

multiple-choice.question: What is the cause of sleep paralysis, according to modern scientists?

options.label: A
options.text: An abnormal overlap of the REM and waking stages of sleep.

options.label: B
options.text: A lack of sleep disorders such as narcolepsy.

options.label: C
options.text: A combination of a person's fear response and their brain being wide awake while their body is in an REM sleep state.

options.label: D
options.text: A demon or evil entity trying to suffocate the person.

multiple-choice.question: What happens to a person's breathing during an episode of REM sleep?

options.label: A
options.text: Their breath becomes more shallow and rapid.

options.label: B
options.text: Their breath becomes more deep and slow.

options.label: C
options.text: Their breath remains the same as when they are awake.

options.label: D
options.text: Their breath is no change in their breathing.

multiple-choice.question: What is the perceived sensation of pressure on the chest or suffocation during a sleep paralysis episode caused by?

options.label: A
options.text: The person's fear response to a perceived attack by an evil creature.

options.label: B
options.text: The combination of the person's body's fear response and their brain being wide awake while their body is in an REM sleep state.

options.label: C
options.text: The struggle for air while the body sleeps.

options.label: D
options.text: The person's brain being unconscious and fully asleep.

title: What's below the tip of the iceberg? - Camille Seaman

multiple-choice.question: What is the primary reason why icebergs are mostly underwater?

options.label: A
options.text: The weight of the snow on the glacier is too heavy to support the ice above the water.

options.label: B
options.text: The density of pure ice is less than that of sea water.

options.label: C
options.text: The shape of the underwater portion is difficult to discern by looking at the above-surface portion.

options.label: D
options.text: The temperature of the water is too cold to support the ice.

options.label: A
options.text: One to two years

options.label: B
options.text: Three to six years

options.label: C
options.text: Five to ten years

options.label: D
options.text: Ten to twenty years

options.text: Bergie Seltzer

options.label: B
options.text: Iceberg Crunch

options.label: C
options.text: Glacier Groan

options.label: D
options.text: Sea Ice Scream

options.label: A
options.text: Growlers

options.label: B
options.text: Bergy bits

options.label: C
options.text: Small icebergs

options.label: D
options.text: Large icebergs

options.label: A
options.text: Thermal currents

options.label: B
options.text: Iceberg Eddy

options.label: C
options.text: Freshwater Halo

options.label: D
options.text: Sea Ice Ring

title: A rare, spectacular total eclipse of the sun - Andy Cohen

multiple-choice.question: What is a total solar eclipse, and what is unique about it?

options.label: A
options.text: It is a rare event where the Moon is too far from Earth, and the Sun appears as a small disc.

options.label: B
options.text: It is a unique event where the Moon's shadow falls on the entire Earth, and the sky remains bright.

options.label: C
options.text: It is a rare event where the Moon perfectly covers the disc of the Sun, and its shadow creates a narrow path across Earth.

options.label: D
options.text: It is a common event where the Moon and Sun are not aligned, and the sky remains dark.

multiple-choice.question: Why do solar eclipses occur several times a year, but most of them are partial eclipses?

options.label: A
options.text: Because the Moon is too far from Earth to completely cover the Sun.

options.label: B
options.text: Because the Moon's orbit is not perfectly aligned with the Earth's orbit.

options.label: C
options.text: Because the Moon doesn't quite line up with the Sun, and the sky remains bright.

options.label: D
options.text: Because the Earth is too small to cover the Sun's corona.

multiple-choice.question: What is the significance of the Moon's distance from Earth in relation to solar eclipses?

options.label: A
options.text: The Moon is too close to Earth, and the eclipses are more frequent.

options.label: B
options.text: The Moon is too far from Earth, and the eclipses are less frequent.

options.label: C
options.text: The Moon is at just the right distance to cause a total solar eclipse yet not block the Sun's corona.

options.label: D
options.text: The Moon's distance has no effect on solar eclipses.

multiple-choice.question: What is unique about the corona of the Sun during a total solar eclipse?

options.label: A
options.text: It appears as a bright disc around the dark disc of the Moon.

options.label: B
options.text: It appears as a dark ring around the bright disc of the Sun.

options.label: C
options.text: It appears as a fiery ring around the dark disc of the Moon.

options.label: D
options.text: It appears as a small dot on the surface of the Sun.

multiple-choice.question: Why is it essential to use specially tinted filters to observe the Sun during a total solar eclipse?

options.label: A
options.text: To block out the Sun's corona.

options.label: B
options.text: To see the Moon's shadow on the Earth's surface.

options.label: C
options.text: To protect the eyes from the Sun's intense radiation.

options.label: D
options.text: To observe the Sun's surface features.

options.label: D

options.label: A

options.label: B

options.text: In the context of describing a slang term used on college campuses to describe failure.

options.label: D

options.label: B
options.text: The word "fizzle" comes from the Old English word "fist" meaning "to break wind without noise".

title: Got seeds? Now add bleach, acid and sandpaper - Mary Koga

multiple-choice.question: What is the primary purpose of scarification in seed germination?

options.label: A
options.text: To increase the seed coat's thickness

options.label: B
options.text: To make the seed coat harder

options.label: C
options.text: To help the seed embryo emerge from the seed coat

options.label: D

options.text: Germination

options.label: B
options.text: Scarification

options.label: C
options.text: Photosynthesis

options.label: D
options.text: Respiration

options.text: Filing down the seed coat with sandpaper

options.label: B
options.text: Soaking the seeds in water

options.label: C
options.text: Nicking the seed coat

options.label: D

options.label: B

options.label: C

options.label: D
options.text: Because it will make the seed coat more susceptible to mold

multiple-choice.question: What should be done to the seeds after applying any of the scarification methods?

options.label: B

options.label: C

options.label: D
options.text: They should be buried in the ground

title: The moral dangers of non-lethal weapons - Stephen Coleman

multiple-choice.question: What is one of the main reasons why military personnel are sent to do jobs that are typically done by police officers in their own countries?

options.label: A
options.text: Because police officers are not available to do the job.

options.label: B
options.text: Because military personnel are more skilled and trained to do the job.

options.label: C
options.text: Because military personnel are available and can do the job quickly.

options.label: D
options.text: Because military personnel are more cost-effective than police officers.

multiple-choice.question: What is one of the problems that has been suggested with the use of non-lethal weapons by military personnel?

options.label: A
options.text: They may be used indiscriminately.

options.label: B
options.text: They may be used as a lethal force multiplier.

options.label: C
options.text: They may not be effective in certain situations.

options.label: D
options.text: They may be too expensive to use.

multiple-choice.question: What happened during the Braga theater surge in Moscow in 2002, which was used as an example of the indiscriminate use of non-lethal weapons?

options.label: A
options.text: The Russian special forces used lethal force to kill the hostage takers.

options.label: B
options.text: The Russian special forces used non-lethal gas to render the hostages unconscious, but many of them died as a result.

options.label: C
options.text: The Russian special forces used a combination of lethal and non-lethal force to resolve the situation.

options.label: D
options.text: The Russian special forces did not use any force to resolve the situation.

multiple-choice.question: What is one of the problems with the way that people are trained to use non-lethal weapons, according to the speaker?

options.label: A
options.text: They are not trained to use them in real-world situations.

options.label: B
options.text: They are not trained to use them in a controlled environment.

options.label: C
options.text: They are not tested to see if they can use them effectively.

options.label: D
options.text: They are not taught to use them in a way that is consistent with the principles of military use of force.

multiple-choice.question: What is the speaker's opinion on the idea of a "perfect" non-lethal weapon that is nasty enough to make people comply, but does not leave any lasting effects?

options.label: A
options.text: He thinks it is a good idea and that it would be effective in all situations.

options.label: B
options.text: He thinks it is a bad idea and that it would be used to abuse people.

options.label: C
options.text: He thinks it is a neutral idea and that it would depend on the situation.

options.label: D
options.text: He thinks it is a good idea, but that it would be difficult to implement.

options.label: C
options.text: Max Wertheimer

options.label: D
options.text: Hugo MÃ¼nsterberg

options.text: 10 frames per second

options.label: C
options.text: 20 frames per second

options.label: D
options.text: 50 frames per second
